layer.title: Queer Poems on places and lovers
layer.text:
A reference map for the A 1000 Channels platform with poems of queer writers. TBC.

If you have contributions, questions or comments to either this map or to our project, feel very welcome to contact us! Give us a shout, if you want to use this mapping tool for your LGBTIQ+ project or your queer narratives! If you have noticed a bug or miss a feature of this mapping client, please post an issue at the public repository for this client at GitHub.

places.title: Michael Field: A Girl
places.teaser:
A Girl,
     Her soul a deep-wave pearl
Dim, lucent of all lovely mysteries;
     A face flowered for heart’s ease,
     A brow’s grace soft as seas
     Seen through faint forest-trees:
     A mouth, the lips apart,
Like aspen-leaflets trembling in the breeze
From her tempestuous heart.
Such: and our souls so knit,
I leave a page half-writ —
     The work begun
Will be to heaven’s conception done,
     If she come to it.

Michael Field

(Michael Field was the pseudonym of the partners Katherine Harris Bradley and Edith Emma Cooper, who lived in Bristol, England in the 19th Century and published unter this pseudonym their poems. See "Inventing Michael Field" by Michelle S. Lee

images.title: Katherine Harris Bradley & Edith Emma Cooper
images.creator: Unknown author

places.title: Sappho: A Poem
places.teaser:
1          Immortal Aphrodite, on your intricately brocaded throne,
            child of Zeus, weaver of wiles, this I pray:
            Dear Lady, don’t crush my heart
            with pains and sorrows.

5          But come here, if ever before,
            when you heard my far-off cry,
            you listened. And you came,
            leaving your father’s house,
            yoking your chariot of gold.

10        Then beautiful swift sparrows led you over the black earth
            from the sky through the middle air,
            whirling their wings into a blur.
            Rapidly they came. And you, O Blessed Goddess,
            a smile on your immortal face,

15        asked what had happened this time,
            why did I call again,
            and what did I especially desire
            for myself in my frenzied heart:
            “Who this time am I to persuade

20        to your love? Sappho, who is doing you wrong?
            For even if she flees, soon she shall pursue.
            And if she refuses gifts, soon she shall give them.
            If she doesn’t love you, soon she shall love
            even if she’s unwilling.”

25        Come to me now once again and release me
            from grueling anxiety.
            All that my heart longs for,
            fulfill. And be yourself my ally in love’s battle.

1         Some say an army of horsemen,
            some of footsoldiers, some of ships,
            is the fairest thing on the black earth,
            but I say it is what one loves.

5          It’s very easy to make this clear
            to everyone, for Helen,
            by far surpassing mortals in beauty,
            left the best of all husbands
           and sailed to Troy,

10        mindful of neither her child
            nor her dear parents, but
            with one glimpse she was seduced by
            Aphrodite. For easily bent...
            and nimbly...[missing text]...

15        has reminded me now
            of Anactoria who is not here;
            I would much prefer to see the lovely
            way she walks and the radiant glance of her face
            than the war-chariots of the Lydians or

20        their footsoldiers in arms.

1          That man to me seems equal to the gods,
            the man who sits opposite you
            and close by listens
            to your sweet voice

5          and your enticing laughter—
            that indeed has stirred up the heart in my breast.
            For whenever I look at you even briefly
            I can no longer say a single thing,
            but my tongue is frozen in silence;

10        instantly a delicate flame runs beneath my skin;
            with my eyes I see nothing;
            my ears make a whirring noise.
            A cold sweat covers me,
            trembling seizes my body,

15        and I am greener than grass.
            Lacking but little of death do I seem.

Sappho, antike griechische Dichterin (~ 630 und 612 bis 570 v. Chr.)

Quelle: Poems of Sappho, Translated by Julia Dubnoff

places.title: Walt Whitman: City of Orgies
places.teaser:
City of orgies, walks and joys,

City whom that I have lived and sung in your midst will one day make you illustrious,

Not the pageants of you, not your shifting tableaus, your spectacles, repay me,

Not the interminable rows of your houses, nor the ships at thew harves,

Nor the processions in the streets, nor the bright windows with goods in them,

Nor to converse with learn'd persons, or bear my share in the soiree or feast;

Not those, but as I pass O Manhattan, your frequent and swift flash of eyes offering me love,

Offering response to my own—these repay me,

Lovers, continual lovers, only repay me.

images.title: Walt Whitman and Bill Duckett
images.creator: New York Public Library
